children.name: promise
children.definition: to tell someone that you will definitely do or provide something or that something will happen:
examples: Last night the headmaster promised a full investigation.
promise to do something
She’s promised to do all she can to help.
promise (that)
Hurry up – we promised we wouldn’t be late.
promise somebody (that)
You promised me the car would be ready on Monday.
‘Promise me you won’t do anything stupid.’ ‘I promise.’
promise something to somebody
I’ve promised that book to Ian, I’m afraid.
promise somebody something
The company promised us a bonus this year.
‘I’ll be back by 1.00.’ ‘Promise?’ ‘Yes! Don’t worry.’
He reappeared two hours later,as promised.

children.name: give sb your word
children.definition: especially spokento promise sincerely that you will do something or that something is true – often used when you are trying to persuade someone that they can trust you:
examples: Campus officials had given her their word. There was to be a raise in salary each year.

children.name: give sb your word (that)
examples: I give you my word that your money is safe with me.
I’ll let you go out tonight if you give me your word that you’ll be home by 11.

children.name: give sb your word of honour/honor
examples: He had given her his word of honor that he would respect her wishes.

children.name: guarantee
children.definition: to promise that you will make sure that something will definitely happen, so that there is no question of it not happening:
examples: The king had guaranteed our safety on our journey.
guarantee (that)
I guarantee you’ll love this film.
guarantee sb sth
If you send the application form in straight away, I can guarantee you an interview.
guarantee to do sth
I cannot guarantee to work for more than a year.
The law guarantees equal rights for men and women.
guaranteed[adj] được bảo hành
same day delivery guaranteed
The fridge is guaranteed for one year. the company that makes it promises to repair or replace it if it breaks within a year

children.name: swear
children.definition: 1 promise to promise that you will do something
examples: swear (that)
Victor swore he would get his revenge.
swear to sb (that)
I swore to myself that I’d never do anything like it again.
swear to do something
Mona swore never to return home.
Do youswear on your honour(= promise very strongly )that you will never tell anyone?
2 public promise[I o T] to make a public official promise, especially in a court of law
swear on
Witnesses have to swear on the Bible.
Remember that you havesworn an oathand so must tell the truth.
swear allegiancepromise to be loyal to a country thề trung thành
New citizens are asked to swear allegiance during the citizenship ceremony.
Presidents mustswear allegianceto the US constitution.

children.name: commit
children.definition: to make a firm and definite promise to do something important, which will affect you for a long time and which could result in serious effects if you fail: cam kết
examples: committed[adj] be committed to doing something: cam kết làm gì
The church is committed to changing the role it allows women.

children.name: commit somebody to doing something
examples: He has clearly committed his government to continuing down the path of economic reform.

children.name: commit somebody to something
examples: Meeting them doesn’t commit us to anything.

children.name: commit yourself
examples: I’d committed myself and there was no turning back.

children.name: commit yourself to (doing) something
examples: The banks have committed themselves to boosting profits by slashing costs.

children.name: pledge
children.definition: to make a formal, usually public, promise that you will do something, or example to give help or money: bảo đảm, hứa
examples: pledge sth to
Moore pledged $100,000 to the orchestra at the fund-raising dinner.
pledge support/money/help etc
Britain has pledged £1.3 million to the UN for refugee work.
The U.S. has pledged aid to the country
pledge (your) support/loyalty/solidarity etc
He pledged his cooperation.
pledge allegiancepromise to be loyal to a country
Should new citizens of Canada pledge allegiance to the queen of Great Britain?
pledge to do sth
The new governor pledged to reduce crime.
pledge yourself to (do) sth
Trade unions pledged themselves to resist the government plans.
pledge that
Herrera pledged that his company will give aid to schools.

children.name: vow
children.definition: to firmly promise something, especially to yourself - used especially in literature: thề, nguyện

children.name: vow to do something
examples: Ben vowed to avenge his mother’s death.

children.name: vow (that)
examples: Daley vowed that the Police Department would be reformed.

children.name: undertake
children.definition: to make an official or legal promise to do something: cam kết, cam đoan

children.name: undertake to do sth
examples: The government undertook to keep price increases to a minimum.
The two sides undertook to respect each other’s territory.

children.name: undertake that
examples: The government undertookthatthe buildings would not be redeveloped.

children.name: assure
children.definition: to tell someone that something will definitely happen or is definitely true, so that they are less worried or more confident: đảm bảo, cam đoan
examples: The document is genuine,I can assure you.

children.name: assure sb (that)
examples: The doctor assured me that I wouldn’t feel any pain.
The airline has assured travellers there will be no further delays.

children.name: assure sb of sth
examples: The dealer had assured me of its quality.

children.name: promise
children.definition: a statement that you will definitely do or provide something or that something will definitely happen

children.name: make a promise
examples: I made a promise to my mother that I’d look after Dad.

children.name: keep a promise
children.definition: alsofulfil a promiseBritish English,fulfill a promiseAmerican English formal
examples: (= do what you promised to do )She said she would come back, and she kept her promise.|The mayor has fulfilled his promise to get tough on corruption.

children.name: break a promise
children.definition: not do what you promised to do
examples: Once again, the government has broken its promises.

children.name: go back on your promise
children.definition: break it
examples: They were angry that the company had gone back on its promise.

children.name: renege on a promiseformal
children.definition: break it
examples: It is tempting for the government to renege on its promise.

children.name: have sb’s promise
children.definition: they have promised you something
examples: ‘It’ll remain a secret?’ ‘Yes, you have my promise.’

children.name: hold somebody to their promise
children.definition: make them keep it
examples: The next day, Gareth held me to my promise to take him fishing.

children.name: a solemn promise
examples: As governor, I made a solemn promise to defend the laws of the Republic.

children.name: a firm promise
children.definition: definite
examples: What had happened to all those firm promises of help?

children.name: a vague promise
children.definition: not definite
examples: Larry made some vague promises to leave his wife.

children.name: a false/empty/hollow promise
children.definition: one that will not be kept
examples: I didn’t make any false promises.

children.name: a broken promise
children.definition: one that has not been kept
examples: There have been too many broken promises.

children.name: a campaign/election promise
examples: He was accused of breaking a campaign promise not to raise taxes.

children.name: promise of
examples: We received promises of support from several MPs.

children.name: promise to
examples: He would never break his promise to his father.

children.name: promise to do sth
examples: She made a promise to visit them once a month.

children.name: promise that
examples: He promised that he’d pick me up.

children.name: vow
children.definition: lời thề nguyện

children.name: make a vow
examples: I made a vow never to go near the place again.

children.name: take a vow
children.definition: make a vow at a formal ceremony
examples: Priests have to take a vow of obedience to the Catholic Church.

children.name: keep a vow
children.definition: do as you promised
examples: She kept her vow not to tell anyone about their affair.

children.name: break a vow
children.definition: fail to do as you promised
examples: She accused him of breaking his marriage vows.

children.name: exchange vows
children.definition: make promises to each other as part of a wedding ceremony
examples: They wanted to exchange vows before their family and friends.

children.name: renew your vows
children.definition: have a second wedding ceremony to repeat your promises
examples: Fifty couples celebrated their golden weddings and renewed their vows at a cathedral service in Chicago.

children.name: a solemn vow
children.definition: a very serious vow, which you must keep
examples: He made a solemn vow that he would do everything he could to help her.

children.name: marriage/wedding vows
examples: She wrote her own marriage vows.

children.name: a holy/sacred vow
examples: When we get married in church we are making sacred vows.

children.name: a vow of silence/poverty/celibacy etc
examples: People close to him have finally broken their vow of silence.

children.name: be bound by a vow
children.definition: to have promised seriously to do something
examples: She told him she was bound by a vow not to tell any other person.

children.name: 1a very serious promise to do something or not to do something that you choose to make
examples: Jim made a vow that he would find his wife’s killer.
2a religious promise that you will do something for God, the church etc :

children.name: a monk who had taken a vow of poverty
assurance
children.definition: a promise that something will definitely happen or is definitely true, which makes someone less worried or more confident: sự đảm bảo
examples: Despite all their assurances, they broke the agreement and signed a deal with a rival company.
Despite my repeated assurances, Rob still looked very nervous.

children.name: assurance that
examples: I need an assurance that you will support me.

children.name: assurance about/on
examples: His lawyer was unwilling to give him any kind of assurance about the outcome of the trial.

children.name: give/seek/receive an assurance
examples: He gave an assurance that the work would be completed by Wednesday.
The manager gave me his personal assurance that the parts would be here today.

children.name: guarantee
children.definition: aformalpromise that something will happen or be provided, because you are going to make sure of this: lời cam kết, đảm bảo

children.name: guarantee that
examples: The contract contains a guarantee that the building will be finished within 6 months.
After the Second World War, Belgium wanted a guarantee that it would not be invaded again..

children.name: guarantee of
examples: I’m afraid there’s no guarantee of success.

children.name: give a guarantee
examples: I cannotgiveaguaranteethat there will be no redundancies.

children.name: commitment
children.definition: 1 a promise to do sth or to behave in a particular way that will take along time or involve a lot of effort:
examples: Are you ready tomakea long-termcommitment?
2[U] the hard work and loyalty that sb gives to an organization, activity etc :
I was impressed by the energy and commitment shown by the players.
commitment to
Her commitment to work is beyond question.

children.name: make a commitment
examples: Getting married involves making a serious commitment.

children.name: give a commitment
examples: The government gave a commitment to withdraw all its forces.

children.name: something requires/demands
children.definition: a
examples: commitmentNursing as a profession demands genuine commitment.

children.name: honour/meet a commitment
children.definition: do what you promised to do
examples: Will they honour their commitment to a ceasefire?

children.name: show/demonstrate commitment
examples: Throughout her life she demonstrated her deep commitment to the needs of the poor.

children.name: lack commitment
examples: I never get promoted because they think I lack commitment.

children.name: reaffirm/restate/reiterate a commitment
children.definition: give a promise again
examples: They reaffirmed their commitment to abandon nuclear power.

children.name: real/genuine commitment
examples: The job demands real commitment to teaching.

children.name: personal commitment
examples: As a company, we expect a personal commitment from our staff to do their best.

children.name: strong commitment
examples: She's known for her strong commitment to women's rights.

children.name: long-term commitment
examples: Having a child together involves a long-term commitment.

children.name: a lifelong commitment
examples: Marriage is a lifelong commitment.

children.name: full/total commitment
examples: Such therapies demand full commitment from the patient.

children.name: political commitment
examples: There was no local political commitment to the proposal.

children.name: religious commitment
examples: Many people have ceased to have any active religious commitment.

children.name: a lack of commitment
examples: His lack of commitment to the project was easy to see.

children.name: a level of commitment
examples: This post demands a high level of commitment.

children.name: commitment to
examples: Our company has a commitment to quality and customer service.

children.name: commitment to doing sth
examples: The governor has a strong commitment to creating jobs in the state.

children.name: pledge
children.definition: a public or official promise to give help, support, or money to an organization, group, or person: lời cam kết (giúp đỡ)
examples: pledge of
a pledge of support for the plan
pledge to do sth
the government’s pledge to make no deals with terrorists

children.name: make/give a pledge
examples: Several European countries made similar pledges.

children.name: take a pledgeliterary
children.definition: make one, especially formally
examples: He took a pledge never to drink again.

children.name: keep a pledge
children.definition: do what you promised to do
examples: He has not kept his election pledges.

children.name: fulfil/honour a pledge
children.definition: more formal than keep
examples: The time is coming when they will have to honour that pledge.

children.name: renege on a pledgeformal
children.definition: not keep it
examples: The government reneged on its electoral pledges.

children.name: an election/campaign/manifesto pledge
examples: The governor had kept her campaign pledge to slash taxes.

children.name: a spending pledge
examples: BrE: I asked him to clarify Labour’s spending pledges.

children.name: a firm pledge
examples: He also gave a firm pledge to build up the National Health Service.

children.name: a solemn pledge
examples: We will not forget. That is a solemn pledge.

children.name: oath
children.definition: a formal and serious promise, especially one that sb makes in a court of law: lời thề, tuyên thệ
examples: an oath of allegiance to the Queen
oath to do sth
Public officials must take an oath to support the U.S. Constitution.
under oathwhile you have made a promise to tell the truth in a court of law
He admitted that he had lied under oath.

children.name: swear/take an oath
examples: As children, they took an oath of friendship.

children.name: violate/break an oath
children.definition: do something you promised not to do
examples: I do not expect you to violate your oath.

children.name: be bound by an oath
children.definition: have sworn an oath
examples: These chiefs were bound to him by oaths of loyalty.

children.name: an oath of loyalty/allegiance/obedience
examples: They swore an oath of allegiance to the crown.

children.name: an oath of secrecy
examples: Anyone who joined had to swear an oath of secrecy.

children.name: the oath of office
children.definition: the oath a government worker swears to do a job honestly and well

children.name: a solemn oath
children.definition: a very serious oath
examples: He swore a solemn oath never to tell.

children.name: a sacred oath
children.definition: one you swear by God
examples: Stephen swore a sacred oath to recognise Matilda as Queen.

children.name: the presidential oath
children.definition: sworn by a new president
examples: the oldest person ever to take the presidential oath for the first time

children.name: the coronation oath
children.definition: sworn by a king or queen when they are crowned

children.name: undertaking
children.definition: a public or official promise to do something, especially something difficult, which needs a lot of effort or money, and that you will be responsible for making sure that it is done: một cam kết

children.name: undertaking to do sth
examples: Khrushchev demanded an American undertaking not to attack Cuba.

children.name: undertaking that
examples: Before we can release you, we need an undertaking that you will not leave town before the trial.

children.name: gave an undertaking
examples: Both organizations gave an undertaking to curb violence among their members.

children.name: I promise
children.definition: used to emphasize a promise, warning, or statement:
examples: ‘Promise me you’ll write to me.’ ‘I promise.’
I promise (that)
I won’t go. I promise I won’t go.
I promise you
I promise you, it does work!

children.name: I give you my word
children.definition: / you have my word spoken say this when you want to make a veryseriousandsincerepromise: tôi hứa
examples: ▪ You won’t regret this - I give you my word.

children.name: I give you my word/you have my word (that)
examples: ▪ I give you my word that I’ll do everything I can.
▪ Do I have your word, Mr Bigelow, that this problem will be corrected?

children.name: cross my heart
children.definition: say this when you are making a promise to sb you know well - used especially by children: tôi xin thề
examples: ‘Do you promise?’ ‘Cross my heart.’
cross my heart and hope to die

children.name: I swear
children.definition: say this when you are making a very firm promise, that you will never break.I swearis used in court: tôi thề
examples: I swear that the evidence I give will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth

children.name: to do what you promised to do
keep
children.definition: your promise/wordB2 to do what you have promised: giữ lời hứa
examples: I made a promise to you and I intend to keep it.
If I make a promise, I like to keep it.
She was crying because she thought he had not kept his promise.
Respect your teenager’s privacy. If you promise not to tell her father, keep your word.

children.name: keep your promise/word to do sth
examples: The government has kept its promise to cut taxes, but this has meant cuts in services, too.

children.name: fulfil
children.definition: British/fulfillAmerican  formal to do what you have promised to do or what you must do, especially in politics or business: hoàn thành lời hứa

children.name: fulfil a pledge/promise/commitment
examples: ▪ Eisenhower finally fulfilled his campaign pledge to end the war in Korea.
▪ In the ROTC program, students fulfill a service commitment after college, in return for a scholarship from the Army or Navy.

children.name: fulfil a duty/mission
examples: ▪ The general did not have confidence that the Fourth Fleet would be able to fulfil its mission.

children.name: stand by
children.definition: / stick to to faithfully keep an earlier promise or agreement although there may now be reasons for not keeping it: giữ vững,
examples: ▪ Despite his family’s opposition, Jake stood by his promise to marry her.
▪ How could she stick to the agreement now that everything had changed so drastically?
▪ I stand by what I said during the campaign.

children.name: be as good as your word
children.definition: use this when you are impressed with sb for doing what they promised to do: giữ đúng lời hứa
examples: ▪ The President promised to lower income taxes, and he’s been as good as his word.

children.name: keep your side of the bargain
children.definition: to do what you promised to do as part of an agreement in which both sides promised to do sth: giữ đúng những gì đã thỏa thuận
examples: The strike has ended. The employers must now keep their side of the bargain and increase overtime pay.

children.name: to not do what you promised to do
break
children.definition: a promise vỡ lời hứa
examples: I said I’d take the girls to the movie, and I don’t like to break a promise.
break a promise to do sth
The government has broken its promise to reduce the size of the army.
broken promise
Despite Roosevelt’s broken promise to balance the budget, he was elected president four times

children.name: go back on
children.definition: sth to change your mind and not do sth that you had earlier promised to do: “quay lưng lại”
examples: He had gone back on his promise to stop drinking too many times.
The rebels had agreed to a ceasefire, but they’ve gone back on their word.

children.name: renege
children.definition: to fail to keep to officially agreed promises or responsibilities: bội ước, thất hứa

children.name: renege on
examples: The government has had to renege on its commitment to full employment.
Kenoco Inc has reneged on its agreement to finance the film.

children.name: to make sure that sb do what they promised
hold sb to
children.definition: to make sure that sb does what they have promised to do
examples: ▪ Parents and teachers need to agree on goals for students, and hold them to it.
▪ Government officials need to be held to their promises.

children.name: warranty
children.definition: a written agreement in which a company selling something promises to repair it if it breaks within a particular period of time

children.name: under warranty
examples: The car is still under warranty.

children.name: guarantee
children.definition: a formal written promise to repair or replace a product if it breaks within a specific period of timeSYN warranty: bảo hành
examples: They offer a two-year guarantee on all their electrical goods.

children.name: have a guarantee
examples: All our boots have a one-year guarantee for being waterproof.

children.name: come with/carry a guarantee
examples: The building work comes with a 30-year guarantee.

children.name: a one-year/two-year etc guarantee
examples: Our clocks carry a five-year guarantee.

children.name: a money-back guarantee
children.definition: one that gives you back the money you paid if there is a problem
examples: The company offers a 30-day, money-back guarantee on all its products.

children.name: a lifetime guarantee
children.definition: one that lasts as long as the object your have bought
examples: The binoculars are covered against manufacturing faults by a lifetime guarantee.

children.name: a full guarantee
children.definition: one that covers all problems
examples: A full guarantee comes with every purchase.

children.name: under guarantee
examples: Is your TV under guarantee(= protected by a guarantee )?

children.name: resolution
children.definition: a promise to yourself to do something: cam kết (với chính mình)
examples: New Year’s resolution(= a resolution made on January 1st)
resolution to do sth
Carol made a resolution to work harder at school.
make a resolution
I made a resolution to give up chocolate.
